   Patient is an 86 year old male with past medical history of coronary
   artery disease status post bypass, atrial fibrillation, chronic renal
   insufficiency, COPD, and bladder cancer who presents from a nursing
   home with altered mental status, intubated in the ED for airway
   protection.

   difficult to say what initiated change in mental status. Differential
   includes infection (especially after aspiration event, urinary source
   in setting of recent instrumentation, prostatitis), arrhythmia,
   seizure, retention of CO2 in setting of history of COPD (ABG at time of
   admission AFTER intubation demonstrated hypercarbia). Stroke in setting
   of AF (not anticoagulated) seems less likely given patient was reported
   to move all extremities, respond to some commands. Head CT negative for
   bleed or other acute pathology. No new medications to account for
   change in mental status.
   Lactate 1.5.
   - Based on CXR and CT that imaged part of the base of lungs, there is
   concern for aspiration pneumonia given dependant findings; treat for 7
   day course abx for hospital-acquired pathogens
   - Follow up repeat ABG, goal CO2 about 50
   - Toxicology screen: negative
   - Abd/pelvis CT negative for any RP bleed or other acute pathology
   - No signs of RV strain, tachycardia to suggest PE (consideration given
   concurrent malignancy).
   - Ruled out MI (less likely), suspect elevated troponin is in setting
   of renal failure, CK's flat.
   - Monitor on telemetry for arrhythmia
   - Urine, blood cultures. Sputum cultures if possible.
   - Appreciate Neuro c/s
   - MRI brain: prelim no acute pathology, await final read
   - Attempted LP, difficult to position, unable to obtain CSF; will
   reattempt today, unlikely bacterial meningitis, concern for
   carcinomatous meningitis given malignancy
   - EEG today
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Intubated initially for airway protection given
   concerns about his mental status.
   - Off sedation.
   - Did well on 0/5.
   - Treating for pneumonia (Hospital-acquired given recent admission),
   will hold off on adding additional gram negative coverage given
   arrhythmias and concern for prolongation of QTc (and difficult to say
   if patient truly has consolidation).
   - Currently does not appear to be CHF exacerbation

   on monitoring and EKG, with some PVCs. On EKG, rhythm appears regular,
   but alternatively patient could be in slower atrial fibrillation. No
   history of digoxin use, other consideration would be hypoxia,
   reperfusion, or this could be patient's baseline.
   - Rule out MI
   - Checking electrolytes
   - Monitoring on telemetry.
   - Holding beta-blocker given episode of bradycardia.
   - Similar to prior EKGs.
   .
